awd_titl_txt: Clear Path - Bachelor's Degree Completion Scholarships
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at East Stroudsburg University of Pennsylvania will increase the timely baccalaureate degree completion rate among students transferring from community college in selected STEM fields. The Clear Path Project will include partnerships with Lehigh Carbon County Community College, Luzerne County Community College, and Northampton County Community College. Students transferring to four-year degree programs frequently lack critical prerequisite coursework and knowledge resulting in many students leaving STEM or slowing their time towards graduation. STEM transfer students are also less likely to develop campus level social support or participate in high impact practices like undergraduate research, peer mentoring and community-based learning. Through Clear Path, the partnering schools will provide cohort activities, social support, and scholarships to students who begin their education in an open access environment to aid in timely baccalaureate degree completion.  The project will study how involvement in these high impact practices by community college students prior to transferring leads to improvements in student success such as increased retention and reduced time to degree completion. Scholarships and support for academically strong students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will help to produce a well-trained STEM workforce that will contribute to the economic growth of Pennsylvania and the nation.

The program organization is informed by research indicating that a significant reason for STEM attrition of community college transfer students is incomplete preparation prior to transfer both in terms of prerequisite courses and the skills and behaviors associated with persistence and success in STEM degree completion. Through Clear Path, promising community college STEM students will be identified and recruited for program scholarships during their first year at community college. This group of students will also begin receiving support, training, and mentoring while still at a community college. The social support and cohort activities will aid in the development of academic adaptive psychological mechanisms, for example, persistence and study behaviors, associated with college student success. How the developmental mechanisms associated with academic success are affected by specific high impact practices will be evaluated. A multivariate examination of the association between the developmental mechanisms and academic achievement, with and without the inclusion of demographic data, will also occur. Further investigation of the role of the cohort activities will clarify how each activity facilitates student participation in high impact practices, improves developmental mechanisms, and results in ultimate academic success.  Any differences seen in the benefits of providing resources while students are still enrolled in community college versus only after they matriculate to a four-year institution can also be evaluated. Information from all of these findings can be used to inform policies and practices at community colleges and four-year institutions. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community and help increase understanding of the attributes and practices of successful student scholarship and support programs for community college transfer students.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of Clear Path - Bachelor's Degree Completion Scholarships was to promote associate degree completion and timely baccalaureate degree completion among community college STEM transfers to East Stroudsburg University (ESU), particularly for underrepresented populations.  Additionally, the program sought to create a Clear Path to graduation by establishing increased communication and curriculum coordination among East Stroudsburg University and regional community college partners, Lehigh Carbon Community College, Northampton Community College, and Luzerne County Community College.  Clear Path-led cross institutional cooperation ensured that students entered ESU from community colleges with appropriate prerequisites and established the associate degree as the appropriate step towards bachelors’ completion.  Enhanced communication between all partners has resulted in increased numbers of partnerships and articulation agreements which outline course sequence and ensure course transfer and student preparedness.  Increased communication and trust among community college and university faculty has established a culture of student advocacy and support.

Clear Path scholars were assisted financially via the S-STEM scholarship. Additional support included enhanced advising, readily available tutoring, cohort and community building activities, and peer mentoring which eased the difficult transition from community college to university.  Via monthly Success Seminars, Clear Path scholars were educated about and supported in the development of traits associated with academic success., e.g., grit, professional sense of self, and help seeking behaviors.  The Clear Path team employed a Translational Developmental Science approach, applying fundamental, lab-based research concerning student development to improve STEM student success. The Clear Path team worked to understand which program components were most responsible for scholar success.  Clear Path program support and scholar success seminars resulted in significant increases in scholar’s grit, help seeking behavior, academic mindset, self-confidence, self-efficacy, and career engagement. Using these data, resources were deployed efficiently, informing Clear Path program methodologies and also establishing effective practices for future support of transfer students beyond the Clear Path program.

Clear Path identified practiced and refined a holistic advising methodology, shared among all partners, that provided scholars with consistent support towards achieving their academic goals. The advising model included three major components, proactive, developmental and advocacy. The proactive advising approach sought to anticipate and solve problems before they occurred or became entrenched.  The developmental advising element insured academic and campus mechanisms, practices and procedures were communicated at a level appropriate to each student.  The advocacy advising component included faculty advisors using their campus knowledge, connections and resources to help students identify and overcome barriers.  Students reported that Clear Path advising was a critical component of their success at ESU, promoting a sense of security as they perceived “someone had their backs”.  The program outcomes, including the Proactive Developmental Advocacy (PDA) advising model, were widely disseminated through two publications and 28 conference presentations to date.

In total, Clear Path supported 126 scholars with a cumulative program retention of 85% (STEM BS conferral rate) and 70% associate degree completion rate.  One-hundred seven degrees across the STEM fields of biochemistry, biotechnology, chemistry, chemical biotechnology, computer science, computer security, environmental science, marine science, mathematics, and physics were awarded.  The time from community college departure to bachelor’s conferral was significantly decreased, with 78.6% of scholars achieving their STEM BS degree in 5 or fewer semesters post transfer from community college (baseline 40%).  Decreased time to degree conferral has a major impact on reducing student debt and increases time in the workforce. Of 76 bachelors STEM graduates who are more than 6 months post baccalaureate conferral, 46 (61%) are employed in STEM; 25 (34%) are seeking advanced degrees.   Clear Path scholars performed well academically maintaining a median GPA of 3.54 on a 4.0 scale.  Clear Path achieved significant increases in enrollment for all STEM underrepresented groups: women +26%, nontraditional students +27%, underrepresented minority students +14%, and Pell eligible students +42%.  Increases presented are compared to historical percentages of underrepresented populations at ESU.  These successes were realized despite closures, delays, and challenges presented by the COVID-19 pandemic. 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Teresa M Jones-Wilson
